text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Greek Cypriot press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Vice chairman of right-wing Disy seeks better coordination with the government with his proposal for the creation of a shadow cabinet.
- Auditors of cooperative credit societies disclose serious discrepancies in the way co-ops operate in a report to the government.
- Disy and centre-right Diko have further consultations on the possibility of a pact in December's municipal elections.
- Cypriot hijacked vessel is still held in a Chinese port, one year on.
- Turkey must take positive action to improve its human rights record if it wants to retain normal relations with the European Parliament, says socialist leader Pauline Green.
- The Cyprus Electricity Authority is accused of bending tender regulations to give power station contract to a specific company.
- Diko leader Spyros Kyprianou refuses to retract his statement that he has lost trust in the justice minister. He is due to discuss the issue with the president today.
- Europe will give 12 million ECUs to support initiatives associated with solving the Cyprus problem.
- Britain and America are promoting a solution to the Cyprus problem based on a confederation, tailored to the needs of Turkey.
- 'If I didn't trust a minister I would sack him,' says President Glafcos Clerides to criticism over the performance of justice minister Alecos Evangelou.
